headline: Ron Paul offers an alternative solution to fixing America's illegal immigration problem
subHeadline: Guests: Katrina Pierson, Anthony Scaramucci, Andy Biggs, Ron Paul, Tonya Reiman, Diamond, Silk, Brittni De La Mora

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.sentences: Welcome to "Watters' World," I'm Jesse Watters.  Liberal humiliation - that is the subject of tonight's "Watters Words." In political warfare, one of the goals is to make your opponent look bad.  Sometimes your opponents do that to themselves and that is what happened to the left this week.  Exhibit 1, Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer delivered the Democratic response to President Trump's Oval Office address on the border crisis.  Forty million viewers tuned in to see Nancy and Chuck after the President standing awkwardly together at the podium - just one podium.  Americans were more amused by their presentation than informed, and the duo got roasted hard on social media.  Here are some of the best memes: "American Gothic anyone."  How about, "The twins from "The Shining.'"  "Super villains."  There they are, I think that's the Joker in "Batman."  And speaking of super villains, how about this, "I see Pelosi went with the Dr. Evil outfit.  Who wore it better?"  And many saw Nancy and Chuck as parents, "We're not mad, we're just disappointed."  And my favorite Face Swap, terrifying.  As Greg Gutfeld said the other day on "The Five," their response should have been followed by quote unquote, "Paid for by Donald Trump for President." Exhibit 2, another political opponent of the President, CNN White House correspondent Jim Acosta went down to McAllen, Texas on the U.S.-Mexican border.  Acosta doesn't want a wall and doesn't believe that there is any crisis at the border, but he posted a video that destroyed his own argument.

utterances.speaker: JIM ACOSTA, CORRESPONDENT, CNN
utterances.sentences: Here are some of the steel slats that the President has been talking about right here.  As you can see, yes you can see through these slats to the other side of the U.S.-Mexico border, but as we're walking along here we're not seeing any kind of imminent danger. There are no migrants trying to rush toward this fence here in the McAllen, Texas area.  As a matter of fact, there are some other businesses behind me along this highway.  There's a gas station, Burger King and so on, but no sign of the national emergency that the President has been talking about.  As a matter of fact, it's pretty tranquil down here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Hey, Jim perhaps it's tranquil because there's a border fence.  Migrants aren't rushing towards the fence because there's a fence.  The illegals cross where there's no fence.  My gosh.  Is Jim Acosta working for President Trump or CNN?  Sometimes it's hard to tell.  What an embarrassment. Exhibit 3, potential Democratic Presidential candidate Beto O'Rourke, a sensation on social media likes to bring voters into his world.  Usually, he livestreams himself cooking steak in the kitchen, things like that, but Beto took it a step too far this week.

utterances.speaker: BETO O'ROURKE, D-TX, FORMER SENTATE CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: So, I'm here at the dentist and we're going to continue our series on the people of the border and I'm here with Diana, my dental hygienist.  Diana is going to tell us a little bit about growing up in Memphis.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Beto, hopefully you don't have a colonoscopy anytime soon.  Sometimes more is less, sometimes less is more.  So there you have it.  Democrats humiliating themselves and Republicans didn't even have to lift a finger.  I wish politics could always be this easy.   Here with me now, senior advisor to the Trump 2020 campaign, Katrina Pierson and former White House Communications Director Anthony Scaramucci, the author of "Trump:  The Blue Collar President," which I read and I highly endorse. All right, guys what did you guys think about my brilliant commentary?  I mean, they just shot themselves in the foot and the Republicans didn't even have to squeeze the trigger.  Go ahead, Katrina.  Ladies first.  KATRINA PIERSON, SENIOR ADVISOR, TRUMP 2020 CAMPAIGN:  Well, you know, look, Jesse, this was really karma.  You have CNN and Jim Acosta specifically who spend the majority of their days trying to undermine the President and undermine his agenda with a ton of fake news and it turns out, it all came back around full circle today and yesterday, and it's going to continue moving forward because the President has been very courageous in pushing forth very bold policies to secure the southern border of this country, to protect American citizens and as Jim Acosta pointed out, his position is the right position.  Walls work and CNN just showed the entire country the President is right on this issue.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, CNN really stepped on their message on that one.  Anthony, it would be like some reporter looking at a block just circled with police officers and saying, "You know what?  There's no crime."

utterances.speaker: ANTHONY SCARAMUCCI, FORMER WHITE HOUSE COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean that was a difficult moment but the better part of it I think, Katrina would agree with me was the "Dear diary" tweet from the President.  I mean, it's just vintage Trump trolling and so when I saw that, I mean I had a laugh and then there were people responding saying that you know, they still are enjoying over the "Dear diary" tweet.  So listen, I mean we've got to get through this though and we have to get the government reopened because it's going to eventually start to affect things like the stock market and the economy that there's this high level of dysfunctionality. The President's a hundred percent right, but unfortunately the system requires a compromise so hopefully, they'll get to a compromise and get the government back open again because the President's up 28 to zero in terms of what he's done for the economy and I don't want him to lose his lead going into the 2020 elections.  So let's just put this behind us --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right, this is critical in order to get this government back open, but he's got to get it back open --

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But he's got to get it back open with some sort of funding for a physical barrier.  Let's try the compromise ...

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: No question.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, I am going to be Donald Trump; Anthony, you are going to be Chuck Schumer, I'm sorry and Katrina, you're going to be Nancy Pelosi.  I don't know who I should apologize to more, but you guys agreed to do this, so we have to come to a compromise.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: You just wish me back - you've got hair and the waters, you just wish me bad hair.  I mean that's all it was.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: Lots of hair envy on this show.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Listen no one has a head of hair like you, Anthony.  You know, I wish I had what was beneath the hair though, the brains, and I could make as much money as you did, too.  All right, so listen, we're in a room.  I'm the President, I'm going to say, "Crying Chuck, listen, we need votes in the Senate.  We need what?  Eight Democrat votes in the Senate in order to get this government back up and open, in order to get a physical barrier.  You Senator Schumer, you voted for physical barriers in the past, why can't you give a little and do what you did before in order to reopen the government?"

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: Okay, well Mr. President, we're both New Yorkers, we're here in a huge tug-of-war, so why don't you throw me a bone.  What bone are you going to throw me so that I can deliver you these eight votes?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I already gave you some candy, that's enough bones, but I will say maybe we could talk about DACA and maybe giving some sort of legal status to these young illegal immigrants that were brought here by their parents, can we maybe go back to that deal, $25 billion for wall funding and DACA fix?  Can we do that?

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: So, I think actually he should do that, but he'll probably not want to do that because they're making a lot of money on the fundraising side of resisting the President, so he'll probably say no to that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So I agree.  I agree.  So Nancy, your left-wing caucus, very radical they don't want to budge an inch on any wall funding.  They don't want to do anything on the border.  They want status quo, so Nancy are you going to be able to get your liberal base in line here and treat this as a national security issue instead of a political issue?

utterances.speaker: PIERSON
utterances.sentences: Look, Mr. President, I'm going have to say what my colleague here didn't say and really advise you that this immoral wall is unnecessary because as you had your meeting yesterday with the Border Patrol and we all learned through this meeting, thank you for doing that, that 21 million lethal doses of fentanyl was seized in the last year according to the Lieutenant Governor of Texas. So 21 million lethal doses were seized, so what we really have to do for morals' sake Mr. President is to open the borders that way we can find out just how many lethal doses of heroin would actually come in.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, so the wall that surrounds your property, Nancy is that immoral, too?  Should we tear down that wall as well?

utterances.speaker: PIERSON
utterances.sentences: Well, well you see Mr. President that's different.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, it's different.

utterances.speaker: PIERSON
utterances.sentences: We're not using taxpayer resources to build my wall because, you know, my family is really, really important and we're just talking about people, you know, your average American.  We're not really talking about people who hold positions to make policies in the country.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, so here's what I think --

utterances.speaker: PIERSON
utterances.sentences: You know, this is like, when you're talking about the difference between - Mr. President --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PIERSON
utterances.sentences: I am a woman.  Please, let me finish.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, sorry.  Excuse me.

utterances.speaker: PIERSON
utterances.sentences: We are talking about the difference here between a diet and diabetes, so we have to make sure we're comparing the right thing, Mr. President.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, brilliant analogy, Speaker Pelosi.  Here's what I think we can do with the compromise.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: Where are my bifocals though?  I am going to call my agent.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, you're so --

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: If I had only bifocals --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Anthony, you're supposed to be looking down.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: I would have come across so much more authentic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, you're supposed to be looking down and reading all of your comments, right?  Here's what I think we can do, in order to get this deal done, I will compromise a little bit, but you guys have to compromise.  Every time I speak, I want you, two, Nancy and Chuck, to give a united response right afterwards because I think that contrast makes me look really good.  Can we agree with that?

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: Amen.

utterances.speaker: PIERSON
utterances.sentences: I think that'd be a fantastic idea.  The American people deserve to hear the truth.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: As long as we're at one podium.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, now in all seriousness - in all seriousness, really quickly, 30 seconds each, Anthony I'll begin with you.  We're hearing rumors that the White House is preparing for Ruth Bader Ginsburg to step down from her role.  She's, you know having some health issues.  She's missed a lot of this week because of those health issues, what do you predict will happen if this open seat gets thrown into the mix, politically?

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: Well, it's certainly going to be a Kavanaugh like fire fight, but the thing that I absolutely predict and I think a lot of constitutional scholars agree with me is that Justice Roberts who was appointed by George W. Bush will continue to tack to the center and be a very moderating force on that court.  Why?  You'll have to ask him, but I think that's where he's going.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I would agree with that and Katrina, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: PIERSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes, I have to agree.  I do think that's what's going to happen, but this is also, you know an amazing opportunity to appoint another Supreme Court justice, that definitely takes seriously the nature of the values of the country from the beginning and I think it's upsetting to a lot of people that this particular woman, possibly may be resigning and I personally would like to see another woman appointed to this position.  I think that --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Maybe Amy Barrett.  She was in the running in the last time.

utterances.speaker: PIERSON
utterances.sentences: The President is going to - Amy Barrett, I think would be fantastic and the President is going to continue to make history throughout his presidency, so that's why we're very proud to support him and continue to push his agenda.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean if you think about legacy, I mean even if the President just serves one term, having the opportunity for three Supreme Court justices, I mean absolutely historic.  All right, Nancy and Chuck --

utterances.speaker: PIERSON
utterances.sentences: Amazing.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: Watch the Federal appointments, too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: The Federal appointments, too, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The Federal bench.

utterances.speaker: PIERSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, the judges.  For sure.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Completely packed.  Guys, thank you very much.  Go check out Anthony's book, all right.  There you go.

utterances.speaker: PIERSON
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Jess.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Now, while visiting the southern border Thursday, President Trump reiterated his intention of declaring a national emergency if push comes to shove.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We have the absolute right to declare a national emergency and this is security stuff.  This is a national emergency.  If you don't have a barrier whether it's a steel barrier or a concrete wall, substantial and strong, you're never going to solve this problem.  You're never going to solve it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Arizona Republican Congressman and member of the House Border Security Caucus, Andy Biggs is in complete support of President Trump's stance and he joins me now.  All right, Congressman, we're talking about a border crisis and whether or not a national emergency needs to be declared. Something that was said the other day by a Border Patrol agent in McAllen, Texas really caught my attention.  Let's listen to the sound and then you can react.  Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So far this sector has apprehended folks from 41 different countries.  Just yesterday, we apprehended a 133 people from countries other than Central America and Mexico that includes individuals from India, Pakistan, China, Romania, Ecuador, Nicaragua on and on and on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So I was shocked when I heard that.  A hundred and thirty people apprehended just in one day and Romania, Nicaragua, Pakistan, Pakistan?  Congressman, I don't think anybody ever even knew that was happening.

utterances.speaker: REP. ANDY BIGGS, R-ARIZ.
utterances.sentences: No, it's happening.  People from all over the world have found that a way to enter our country is just to sneak across the southern border, but you know what he didn't say is, they got 133, but ask him how many they thought got away?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's a good point.

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: And the getaways are averaging you know, it depends on who's estimating, but it's four to ten times as much.  So they caught 133, but they might have had anywhere from 600 1,500 people actually crossed the border successfully yesterday.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: So that's a problem, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And I know you're down there on the border in Arizona.  You're hearing from your constituents that a fence or some sort of physical barrier is needed.  We've heard that from the Border Patrol agents as well.  People say it's not a crisis and there's no baseline to declare a national emergency.  Other Presidents have declared national emergencies as well.  I believe -- who was it?  Bill Clinton declared 17 national emergencies.  George W. Bush, 13; President Obama, 12.  I mean, declaring national emergencies is not something like out of thin air, it's been done by other Commanders-in-Chiefs in the past.  Are you hearing that this is in the pipeline?

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, I'm hearing that he's seriously considering it and it's going to trip.  The wire is going to trip soon because Pelosi and Schumer are not willing to negotiate at all.  The radicals within - the House Democrats, they're not willing to budge at all and it is a real crisis. I mean look, President Obama had declared one over swine flu for Pete's sakes and I'm not saying that to diminish the seriousness of swine flu, but we have people crossing our border by the thousands.  We have no idea who they are.  We know that we're catching people who shouldn't be here in the sense that they are criminal illegal aliens.  We know people who are on terrorist watch lists are coming across and I find it hard to believe that that national security implication doesn't rise to the level of an emergency situation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, you mentioned swine flu.  We know in Texas alone just in one year, 32 illegal aliens were convicted of homicide.  Now 32 deaths right there in one year in one state alone, I believe that's more than people died of swine flu, you know, however way you tabulate it, I think you can call it a crisis.  The "Washington Post" declared it a crisis, the media called it a humanitarian crisis last month and now they're saying it's a manufactured crisis. In my opinion, the Democrat policies of open borders, that's created the crisis because that's attracting them and because the legal loopholes, you can't hold people.  You've got to do catch and release and you can't keep people together, you can't separate them.  It's a mess.  Thirty seconds, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: Yes, you're absolutely right.  Look, every year, we find hundreds of people in each of the sectors that have come across the border.  They're trying to get in here illegally.  We find their bodies.  They've been eaten up by animals.  This is a real problem, it's a humanitarian crisis, but it's more than that.  It is actually a national security crisis because of the people who are coming across.  We can build the wall, but if we're not going to do it in Congress, which by the way we've been derelict, we need to let the President declare that emergency and he will be attacked through litigation, but we need to stand firm behind him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, Congressman, thank you very much.  Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Coming up, "The Rock" takes on Snowflakes.  Wait until you hear what he had to say.  But up next, Ron Paul enters "Watters' World" for the very first time.

utterances.speaker: RON PAUL, R-TX, FORMER REPRESENTATIVE
utterances.sentences: I don't like walls.  I am a Libertarian.  I don't want to wall people in.  I don't want to wall people out, but I don't want free open borders either.  I think you have to remove the incentives for people to come.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Former Texas Congressman and three-time Presidential candidate, Ron Paul offering an alternative solution to the immigration problems plaguing our southern border, but has the President's latest pitch for a wall changed his mind. Ron Paul is the host of "The Ron Paul Liberty Report" and joins me now.  All right, welcome to the show, Congressman.

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know that you are a Texas guy for almost all of your career not on the exact border, but kind of in the Gulf area, so you're familiar with the problems of illegal immigration.  You're against the wall and you think we should look inward to create a new reality where we're not attracting so much illegal immigration.  How would that look?

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.sentences: Well, I think it would look a lot different and we would have to educate the people a little bit that we're not owing everybody who comes here illegal a living and a job and school and medical care and the whole works.  Now, I would remove all the incentives and one of the biggest incentives is easy road to citizenship. So I don't happen to believe that an illegal, you know, should get in line for a citizenship, so I'd abolish that.  I think bona fide citizenship ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, let me just ask you a question.  So do you think right now, the way the welfare state is in this country, that is primarily what's attracting illegal immigration or do you think they're coming more for the cash?  Jobs?

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.sentences: I would give the credit - if you're going by numbers, I would say the large number would like to just get here and work because of the money that we come across in Texas.  I think that is the case, but I also think there's a big incentive to become an easy citizen and bring the kids along and this sort of thing.  I don't think that exists in very many other countries. So, yes, I think that's a tremendous incentive.  I think, believe it or not, there might be some political aspects to this where some of the political parties or maybe there's one particular political party that thinks they're going to get more votes that will vote for more welfare.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right, because when you when you bring in the new illegal population, even if they can't vote yet, they're counted towards the census which determines Congressional districting and obviously would help the Democratic Party, they believe, but right now you have the business community which likes the open borders because they like the cheap labor and then you have the Democratic Party which likes the open borders because, as you said they want future voters.  How do you win both sides of the equation or for open borders?  Where is there any middle ground to find the solution?

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't know if there's an exact middle ground say on automatic citizenship or easy citizenship because you're an illegal immigrant.  I just don't think there should be.  There should be no rewards for that.  I think people should you know be prosecuted for this.  But this is a big problem because you know, the citizenship is very, very easy.  I've delivered women who just show up here and they can quickly -- because the child was born here, they can quickly get on welfare and I just don't think that should exist. The whole thing is the people who qualify for welfare and you say, well, if they think it's immoral to build a wall, what would people think if I say I wouldn't even give them any welfare benefit.  Of course, a good Libertarian - a great libertarian doesn't believe in the welfare redistribution anyway. So saying that we're not going to give you this welfare --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They would just call you a mean person and that's usually what the left says when they disagree with you.  So you're talking about attracting illegal immigrants through additional welfare that leads me to the next topic, you have this young Congresswoman Cortez, they call her AOC, she wants universal healthcare which costs, I don't know anywhere between $30 trillion and $40 trillion. If you're someone's south of the border and you hear this new wave of Democrats is going to contemplate giving universal healthcare, doesn't that attract more illegal immigration?

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.sentences: Yes, would be part of it as well.  It would be certainly encouraging and I try to point out to other people, what would it be like if we, as American citizens decide we want to live in Japan and march into Japan and say, "Where do I sign?  How do I become a citizen?  And where will I go for my medical care and where do I get my education?"

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't think the Japanese would welcome us with open arms.

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.sentences: No, this is absurd.  I see our system as sort of masochistic, but I think socialism in many ways is, but sometimes it's designed for that to get more power, a social assert --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So you think the Democratic push towards socialism is all about political power?  Do they have any compassion towards the people?  Do they even believe these systems work because if you look throughout the rest of the world, Venezuela whenever socialism has been tried, it has failed.

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.sentences: I would question it, but I wouldn't let the Republicans get off the hook.  Remember who pushed the prescription health programs and all of these, so the Republicans are great participants in government medicine.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That is true.

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.sentences: But I think - go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Let me talk to you quickly about Syria because I know when you were running for President, you were very much an isolationist that you were against getting involved and especially the Middle East and now this President is going to withdraw about 2,000 troops mostly special operators from Syria.  Do you support that and do you see any unforeseen consequences?

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.sentences: Yes, I support it, but first off, I don't like me being accused of being an isolationist because the a good Libertarian is very open, you know, to trade and other things and I consider the people who put on sanctions and restrict trade and get involved in punishing people.  They're more isolationist than any libertarian would be.  No, on my program, my little program that I have, I was excited about what was happening in Syria and I cheered him on, but I sort of kept my fingers crossed what would happen and lo and behold, you know, it's slowing up there.  It was not going as fast, but I'd do anything to encourage the President to do what's right. He gave the right answers.  What are we doing over there?  And I've - he said he campaigned on bringing them home, so I would say that's very good, but the big problem he has is he doesn't get reinforcements from the very people he appointed. So as long as he has the same people - then they go out and they undermine him and they go around the world and say, "Oh, we didn't really mean that," so --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.sentences: But I think his instincts are good and I think we should not only come home from Syria, but just remember, these countries like Syria and other countries are all set up under emergency powers.  We need to come home and if you're willing to have you know a decent reform in currency and trade, I'll tell you what, it's really the opposite of isolationism.  It's bringing people together in a voluntary manner and that to me, I think should be our goal.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Thank you very much, Congressman Ron Paul, everybody there.

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.sentences: You're welcome.  Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Up next, our body language expert explains Nancy and Chuck's Oval Office speech.  What were they thinking?  And later, we've got a porn star turned preacher.  She will enter "Watters' World."

utterances.speaker: LAUREN BLANCHARD, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Live from "America's News Headquarters," I'm Lauren Blanchard.  President Trump takes on the "New York Times" over its report that the FBI was investigating if he was secretly working for Russia.  It claims the investigation was opened following the firing of then FBI director James Comey.  The White House is calling the accusations absurd. In a tweet earlier, the President said quote, "Wow, just learned in the failing "New York Times" that the corrupt former leaders of the FBI almost all fired or forced to leave the agency for some very bad reasons opened up an investigation on me for no reason and with no proof after I fired lying James Comey, a total sleaze." And explosion rocks Central Paris leaving three people dead.  Two of the killed were fire fighters.  Authorities believe it was caused by a gas leak inside a bakery.  Forty seven people were also injured.  I'm Lauren Blanchard, now back to "Watters' World."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We have all seen Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer's robotic response to President Trump's Oval Office speech on Tuesday, but there's a lot going on with what they're not saying, so our body language expert, Tonya Reiman is back to help us out. All right, Tonya, let's start with Chuck Schumer first.  Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER, D-N.Y., U.S. SENATE MINORITY LEADER
utterances.sentences: The President of the United States having failed to get Mexico to pay for his ineffective, unnecessary border wall and unable to convince the Congress or the American people to foot the bill has shut down the government.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, so what do you see from Chuck, but also what you from Nancy who is standing stiff.

utterances.speaker: TONYA REIMAN, BODY LANGUAGE EXPERT
utterances.sentences: There is nothing worse than going on like nonverbal lockdown, which means you just stand there and hope that nobody can read anything because you're not giving out signals, when in fact not giving out signals gives out strong signals.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What is she doing by locking down?  Why is she doing that?

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: When you see this, it's kind of like she's so robotic, she's trying to wait - so in other words, her turn went, and now she hands over the reins.  What she should have done to break the ice would occasionally look over towards him, to kind of build that rapport and make it look like natural instead of making them look like statues.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: She's trying to disappear because she knows it's Chuck's turn and she's already had her turn.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: I don't know about disappear, but I think she wanted to make it look as natural as she could.  I'm looking at the camera, I'm holding eye contact with that little red dot.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, god.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: And that's kind of the impression that she was trying for.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wow, not a natural.  Okay, let's go and listen to Nancy speak.  Roll the tape.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF., SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE
utterances.sentences: President Trump must stop holding the American people hostage, must stop manufacturing a crisis, must reopen the government.  Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, what was that with her mouth?

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: You know, she went, "To you Chuck."  So, first of all, none of them did well reading off the teleprompter.  They didn't come across as even remotely kind or authentic.  They all - all three of them off the teleprompter at this point looked like they were trying so hard and her voice was completely different than it normally is. She normally has a rather robust voice and here she is reading off that teleprompter and you can hear the difference in the way she's speaking as she has to read --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What was this lip movement where she passes the torch?

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, when she --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What is this?

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: When you do that, see this, this is a mouth tightening, so when you tighten your lips like that it's kind of like disdain and contempt, "Here you go."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: She doesn't like Chuck.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Well there's a lot --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, that's how I'll interpret it.  All right, you don't have to say it.  All right, here's Donald Trump at the wall the other day down at the border.  You know very animated as usual, take a look.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Tell me what you see.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: They come through the border and they go out throughout our nation.  So you'll have crime in Iowa, you'll have crime in New Hampshire, you'll have crime in New York.  You have crime in places -- you know, you don't associated it with the border, but it comes through the border.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Very animated.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, his hands always do frame his words.  That's what he does, but what was good about this was, as he's talking and he's using it.  He's going - it'll be around, so he's consistent and he looks congruent and he sounds like he knows what he's talking about.  So whether you like and agree with the wall or not, he came across strong right here and he's animated and he talks to people as if it's every day and that's a complete disconnect from what he did when he had to speak to the teleprompter.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, and then we don't have time to analyze Senator Cruz sitting there in the back with - maybe we'll get to  that next time.  All right, Tonya, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: REIMAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Still ahead, the porn star turned preacher.  Wait until you see this, but first Diamond and Silk on The Rock body-slamming Snowflakes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: President Trump, addressing the shutdown and border situation in his first ever primetime Oval Office address this week.  Now, the media immediately criticizing his speech, frequent Trump critic Ana Navarro filed her nails while her CNN co-panelists discussed crimes committed by illegal immigrants.  Watch this.

utterances.speaker: STEVE CORTES, POLITICAL COMMENTATOR, CNN
utterances.sentences: Even if I were to grant you that, okay, the point is the illegal aliens crime rate should be zero.  It should be - you can do your nails, you know who can't do their nails?  Are people who have been killed, Ana, by dangerous known illegal aliens who've been allowed to stay in this country because of the leftist policies that people like you promote in so-called sanctuary cities.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wow.  Here with their thoughts, Diamond and Silk.  Pretty callous display by Ana Navarro at CNN, what do you guys think?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND, VIDEOBLOGGER
utterances.sentences: Yes, callous is very disrespectful, she lacked empathy and maybe the reason why she can't empathize - empathize, excuse me with other families that's been severely affected by illegal aliens is because she's not a victim or she hasn't been severely impacted by it.

utterances.speaker: SILK, VIDEOBLOGGER
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: But it's time for her to wake up, smell the coffee, stop acting like a sideshow over there on the fake news.  Call Nancy and Chuck and tell them to fund the wall.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: Fund the wall.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean everybody was weeping when the President's policies were temporarily separating children from their families at the border and now, you have families permanently separated by criminal illegal alien killers and she's filing her nails.  Unbelievable. All right, we played this at the top, Beto O'Rourke running for President, likes to film himself doing everything in his personal life.  Here he is at the dentist, watch this.

utterances.speaker: O'ROURKE
utterances.sentences: So I'm here at the dentist and we're going to continue our series on the people at the border. I'm here with Diana, my dental hygienist.  Diana is going to tell us a little bit about growing up in Memphis.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I mean, kind of a stunt.  I just - I can't take it seriously anymore.  What do you guys think?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: Well if he's doing that because he's going to be running for President, we're just not that into him.  We're not going to be voting for him.  You would think he would use his platform to push for border security for the American people, instead of getting your teeth clean, he's doing something that some Americans can't even do. You have some of our veterans that can't afford to get their teeth cleaned.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: You know, so he's - I don't know, Beto is sick.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: That's right.  Veto Beto.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: That's what we're going to do.  He's a little sick.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, lastly, we have The Rock who tore into Snowflakes.  Listen to what the professional wrestler and actor said.  I think he said something like while the people's champion, he applauded everybody who can be who they want to be.  They said, "So many good people fought for freedom and equality, but this generation are looking for a reason to be offended."  Wow, can you guys smell what The Rock is cooking.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.  Not only that, but you know, you have a lot of these millennials, they want to be disruptive, very disrespectful.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: They feel like their opinion is the only opinion and if you say something other than what they want you to say, you're ostracized, criticized or stigmatized for it and that has got to stop and I'm happy that people like The Rock, and I hope other people, no matter what side of the aisle you are on, start speaking out about it.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: A time for these millennials to realize you do not have a sense of entitlement.  You have to work for what you want and whatever you want to get, you know, if I have an opinion, it's my opinion.  If you have your opinion, it is your opinion.  We have to learn how to agree to disagree when we have a disagreement.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right ladies, Diamond and Silk.  There they are.  Catch them on the "Chitchat Tour."  I think they're coming to D.C., at the Trump Hotel in February.  Go look it up.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.sentences: chitchattour.com.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, now from porn star to preacher.  One of the biggest stars in the adult industry explains why she left in the name of God.  Up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: From porn star to preacher.  Adult film star, Jenna Presley has been hailed as one of the top performers in her fields, making more than 300 films and plenty of money along the way, but she since found God, quit the industry and ditched the stage name.  Brittni De La Mora joins me now. All right, Brittni, take us through this.  How did you get involved in porn?

utterances.speaker: BRITTNI DE LA MORA, FORMER ADULT FILM STAR
utterances.sentences: Well, I got  involved in porn just from I felt very rejected growing up as a child, so I was basically looking for love in all the wrong places. I started dancing in college and a couple of producers came in and they were you know, saying things to me that I didn't hear at home.  They were saying, "You are beautiful.  You're destined to be a star.  We absolutely love you.  We make romance movies.  If you're ever interested, give us a call."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Romance movies, okay.

utterances.speaker: DE LA MORA
utterances.sentences: Yes, nothing romantic about a porno.  I knew what they were talking about and so I figured you know what, I'm already promiscuous and I already take my clothes off for money, so I might as well take it one step further.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So what are the dangers from the porn industry?  Was there a lot of drug abuse?  What did you encounter?

utterances.speaker: DE LA MORA
utterances.sentences: I definitely encountered a lot of drug abuse.  I, myself was hooked on heroin and various different kinds of pills, cocaine and for a short period of time crystal meth.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Were you doing that to numb yourself or were you doing that to get through the scenes?  Why were you so involved in drug use?

utterances.speaker: DE LA MORA
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, it started because I was about 105 pounds and a director told me that I was fat and that I needed to lose weight, so I started using cocaine and it was just like this instant rush, and it actually helps me get through the porn scenes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right and you so you're making a lot of money at the time.  Around how much were you making when you were in the business?

utterances.speaker: DE LA MORA
utterances.sentences: I would make about $30,000.00 month from porn and then in escorting, you know, I could make about $50,000.00 in a weekend in New York.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wow, all right, so that's a lot of money and - but you tried to get out of the business.  Were you successful right away or not?

utterances.speaker: DE LA MORA
utterances.sentences: No, not right away. I tried at my three-and-a-half year mark.  I made Jesus my Lord and Savior.  Satan wasn't happy about my decision, sent a man in my life because men were my weakness.  He was a pimp and I ended up getting back into the adult film industry for another three years or so and this time, I was giving all my money away to a pimp.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Why were you doing that?  Did he have that much control over you?

utterances.speaker: DE LA MORA
utterances.sentences: Yes, you know what, he definitely had that type of power over me.  He won me over through manipulation.  He made me feel like, you know, he made me feel good about myself in the beginning.  He was taking me to church.  He was a backslidden Christian and then from there, you know, he kind of said it's time.  Like, let's get back.  Let's get you back into the adult film industry. I had burned every bridge in my family, so I kind of felt like, all right, this is what I've got to do at this point in my life.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And then eventually, you found God, completely quit the business.  How did that transpire?

utterances.speaker: DE LA MORA
utterances.sentences: So I had started reading the Bible over those next three years that I was with the pimp and I just remember God telling me one day, you know you need to leave him and so God helped me to get away by telling me to call you know, my mother and she came and picked me up within 20 minutes. And I was on my way to film a porn scene in Las Vegas, but I'd brought my Bible, so I had the Bible with me on the airplane and I was reading the Book of Revelation and I read the scripture that basically said you know I have this thing against you, you tolerate that woman named Jezebel.  She leads my people into sexual immorality.  I've given her time to repent and if she doesn't repent, I'll cast her and her children into a sickbed. That's not a very fun scripture to read when on your way to film a porn scene, but then God really started to bring grace to that scripture and he said Brittni, this isn't the life that I have for you.  The life that I have for you is going to overflow with so much peace and so much joy and if you'll just quit the industry today, I'll bless your life like no man ever could. And so I quit the porn industry, I started going to church.  God miraculously healed me from my drug addiction.  I've been sober for six years and now, I get to preach the gospel and I travel the world to evangelize and God has really blessed my life like no man ever could.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, congratulations.  Amazing transformation, amazing personal journey and I'm just glad you're doing well.  Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: DE LA MORA
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much.  Thank you for having me, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, Brittni, thank you.  Up next, "Last Call."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Time now for "Last Call."  We heard about this thing in California.  This guy gets intimate with a doorknob and a doorbell.  We'll show you the whole thing, look at this.  No joke.  Police say this guy, Roberto Arroyo spent three hours lurking around a home in Salinas last week licking the doorbell and even relieving himself in the front yard.  He's also accused of stealing a few extension cords that were used for Christmas decorations.  I wonder what he did with those? The homeowners were away during the incident, but have since spent hours sanitizing their doorbells.  I'm just going to use the knocker.  Wonder if the perp will get a major tongue lashing in court?  I apologize for that. That's all for us tonight.  Be sure to follow me on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter and remember, I'm Watters, and this is my world. Content and Programming Copyright 2019 Fox News Network, LLC.
